In answer to the question of why those of us stay at our Gannett papers: There are few places left to go right now, and I have a family to support. Plus, most of us are pathetic enough to love being at a newspaper, to feel responsible for reporting local news, to love what we do, even though there are many days it feels more like I'm being on an assembly line churning out copy that we don't have enough bodies to do justice to. Then there is the odd good day where we do work that seems to make a difference.
But the bottom line is if we don't do it, who will? Local TV gets all their story ideas from newspapers. The NYT isn't going to report on the local school board vote that affects tens of thousands of kids in my city, or the conflicts of interest in city government or the crazy stuff a local pastor is up to. Gannett is the main source of reporting in many dozens of cities. Other paper companies are similarly cutting staff and resources.

"The readers in towns and cities that are served by Gannett newspapers are finding a lot less news when they open up the morning paper." Give me a break! We lived in Rockland County for 18.5 years and read the Rockland Journal News - on and offline (we had it periodically delivered until we'd get so mad at the delivery person that we'd stop it). It was tiny then. They also dramatically changed the online format. I understand the need to do this (save money) but I felt like we were beta testers (we really were) and were being asked to make suggestions as to how to make it better - WHY ... we weren't being paid to do Quality Assurance work ... we were not testers. But I understand they followed the standard set by Microsoft - put initial garbage out and let the public tell them what the problems are for free.

Then, we moved to Asheville and the Citizen-Times is another Gannett extension and it, too, is tiny. Then Gannett, in all its infinite, highly-paid wisdom, changed the online format again (it's Gannett, so logically, in time, both were in the same annoying format). Now I rarely, rarely read either paper. They're junk papers in addition to small and the software is more than annoying.

It is the way of the world. We are the beta testers of garbage. But guess what? I have a choice. For now, I'm sticking with the NYT and when Gannett falls, it's their own fault.

The subtext of this story is that big media outfits like Gannett have gotten way too big to be of real value to their consumers or nimble enough for the challenges of the Internet age. Instead of downsizing its workforce, while giving undeserved bonuses to its top executives, Gannett should sell off its smaller media properties to investors committed to providing useful news and information to readers in local markets and then focus on upgrading USA Today into a national newspaper that's worth more than stepping over on your way down to the hotel breakfast room.

This is what they teach in business school. Balancing land, labor, capital and management. I can't imagine one person out there that wouldn't do the same thing if they could. If there was a plate in front of you with $20 million on it, and all you had to do is fire some people to get that money, anyone would do it. Even the people writing these long anti-capitalist essays would sell out for probably far less money than $20M.

Gannet is not an exception.  It's the norm and has been for as long as I can remember.  One evil is the spread between the top and the employee's average income.  Collective bargaining may be dieing but the lack of fair employment practices will result in serious economic consequences in the long term.  Systemic poverty is not the road to prosperity.

As a long time Gannett employee, watching the execs stuff their pockets with money is nothing new. The sad thing is knowing how behind the curve the company really is. Currently corporate folks have announced one of their periodic "transformations," which is double-talk for a slogan and a logo to make shareholders think they have something going on. They don't. Those of us out here in the real world consider corporate the enemy. There is no "value added" coming from corporate. it's a sad day for community journalism and democracy.

Gaelic is not a language but a family of languages. If the words were inscribed by Irish Americans, the language is Irish.
Gaelic, like many language families, consists of several different languages, each quite different from the other, and not understandable to those who only speak one language.
If the inscribers were Polish, you would not say that the language inscribed is Slavic. Or if they were French, you would not say that they inscribed in Romantic.
The Gaelic language family is composed of Welsh, Irish, Scottish, and Bretton.

Talk about the luck of the Irish!
In 1976 my husband & I bought a small apartment around the
corner from Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. A few years later
when I decided to paint a small hallway between the bedroom
and the living room I was doing the necessary prep work.
In the hallway, the ceiling was lower than the 9 foot plus
of the other rooms so I tapped it. It moved! There was a
piece of painted plywood resting on the moldings. I removed
it, so gently. And then, discovered a silver tray and a tea
set, incomplete, but pretty. Wow.
Another place we had, in Nantucket, we rented out for short
periods of time in the summer, 2 weeks or less, here and there, when
we were somewhere else, over the course
of 25 years. When we sold the house and moved all the furniture,
I found, lodged in the bracket feet of a bedroom chest of drawers,
a pair of diamond earrings.
Who these tiny treasures belonged to was impossible to figure out.
Another wow.
But, perhaps, the best thing I ever found was when I removed the
floor coverings, some kind of linoleum thing, from the kitchen in
that Nantucket house when we were renovating it. I found old Boston newspapers used for
insulation. It took weeks to remove the coverings because I read all
the newspapers, on my hands and knees, before pulling them up. They were also terribly fragile
and literally dissolved as I removed them. But what a treasure!
Who knew that what we call "Mohawks" now, the hairstyle, not the
Indian family group, were enormously popular in the late 19th
century? They were called "Algonquins" then. And, not so rare
in our time, there were tons of ads in the classifieds for
psychics. Ah, the more things change, etc.
I had a wonderful time with these things.
I found a large bone while digging up part of the garden in order
to plant some tomatoes. I was shocked, thinking it was a human
bone. But, no, much to my happiness, it was the leg bone of a
sheep. I also found arrowheads and tomahawk stones.
I think I just felt so lucky to feel history first hand.

I inadvertently posted a draft of my comment. I would appreciate it if you could replace it with this edited comment:

Tara Parker-Pope's article "The Women's Health Initiative and the Body Politic" characterizes subjects in the study as, “if they still have a uterus”, which makes it seem ordinary. It was a missed opportunity to inform your readers that 1 out of 3 women in the US do not have a uterus because their uteri were surgically removed, and that this is not only not ordinary, it is not acceptable. Not commenting about this astonishing fact implies that it is acceptable.

Over half a million hysterectomies are performed every year in the US. Last month Blue Cross of Michigan acknowledged that two-thirds of hysterectomies are unnecessary. The cost to these women and their families is enormous in health and lost quality of life.

Nora W. Coffey
President, HERS Foundation

Graduated from medical school 20 years ago. Resident and fellow back in the Q3 up all night call era. Now often still working 80 to 100 clinical hours a week, at least 6 in hospital overnight calls a month. Still paying off med school loans. Making the same salary I was making as a general pediatrician over 10 years ago. Usually 4 weekend days off per month, sometimes less.

I agree completely with limiting the number of hours any human being is expected to remain awake and working. One cannot absorb new information or perform complex intellectual or manual skills when one is nauseated, bleary eyed, and increasingly disconnected after lack of sleep for more than 24 to 36 hours. Yep, I ended up in a corn field driving home as a resident too. We all have those stories.

And yet, to answer a question from a previous reader, attending physicians are now taking over the clinical activities that residents used to perform. Resident has to leave for conference, or take a mandated nap, or leave at the end of a shift with no new resident to replace them? "Their" patients have been and still are my responsibility. As an attending physician, I always stay in house on call now, something my supervising attendings never did 15 years ago. Many physicians coming out of residency do not have the same basic procedural skills that we did 15 years ago - so my colleagues and I end up doing those procedures for them. More and more often, we hear comments from residents and medical students similar to those made by the second year med student above - they want to find jobs with minimal or no call, so they can spend time at home with their families. That's fantastic for them - but then, who will care for their patients at night or on school holidays or at other inconvenient times?

I used to love being a doctor. Sleep deprivation, loss of ties with family and friends because I'm always working, loss of outside interests because I can't balance them with my work load and CME hours and administrative responsibilities, and lack of basic human decency from the parents of the children with whom I interact have really eaten away at my initial desire to help children and their families through times of illness. In the last 3 years, I've had a handgun pulled on me in the middle of the ICU, been screamed at by more parents than I can count, been pulled away from and accused of hurting a child who was in shock by his parents as I was trying to start an IV, had a grandparent grab my arm as I was trying to place a central line, watched a colleague get punched and shoved to the floor by a parent, had to call security for protection for a child whose parents were throwing things at each other over her ICU bed, and on and on...

In my humble opinion, we all have to look at ourselves more closely. Physicians in training need to understand that this is not a profession where one should expect immense financial rewards or a 9-to-5 schedule. You really need to LOVE helping people to be here, and that should be reflected in everything you do. Plus, you have to seek out learning opportunities so you are competently trained by the end of residency. However, medical professionals should expect to recoup our significant financial outlays for school and earn a salary which covers the increasing multiple thousands of dollars of licensing and professional fees for which we are responsible. And, especially if we are to be expected to earn what the public deems is a "reasonable" salary (and, yes, my colleagues and I take home less than $130K a year for working 100+ hours a week), then our total number of hours worked must decrease accordingly. Parents and families should expect a physician who listens to them, spends time with them, and who genuinely seems to care what is happening to them and their child/loved one. However, they should also understand that most physicians and other health care professionals are NOT out to deliberately hurt them or to steal from them. There are exceptions in every profession, and such physicians should be dealt with harshly. But, when I'm in a child's room with a nurse and an RT at 2 AM, it's not because of the exorbitant salary any of us are making. We're there because we care and want to help their child get better. And, while grief can be overwhelming, it does not provide an acceptable excuse for physical or verbal violence to nurses, pharmacists, respiratory therapists, housekeepers, physicians, ex wives or husbands, or anyone else helping to provide your loved one's care.

A well rested doctor may be a better doctor. An engaged, empathetic, competently trained, adequately reimbursed, AND well rested doctor, providing care to patients/families who they have and take time to listen to, learn from, care for, earn respect and trust from, take some degree of responsibility for, and can expect not to be physically harmed by, is certainly a better doctor.

Not mentioned in the article is whether any alternative medicine researcher was involved in the design of the study or whether or not the hormones used were bio-identical or synthetic, which makes a huge difference. (Premarin is a synthetic estrogen that includes only the two carcinogentic estrogen components which make up only 10 percent of natural estrogen). If synthetic hormones were used, that would certainly explain some of the negative results observed.

Additionally, a problem affecting this kind of study is that with the complexity of the human system, it is is nigh impossible to ascertain the effect of only one substance while all other variables of lifestyle and diet are uncontrolled. That is why results were all over the map.

I would like to offer my case for an upcoming contest. It has puzzled pcps and other medical experts over the last three years. It was initially diagnosed as Raynaud's syndrome, but after numerous tests, use of calcium channel blockers, moves to warmer climates (Houston, Phoenix), etc., nothing has changed. My hands continue to ache for hours each day with stinging cold all across the knuckles and over the fingers of both hands. Heated gloves help but the cold sensation returns as soon as I take them off. A rheumatologist said I did not display the classic red/blue/white signs of Raynaud's. So the big question is: what seemingly progressive condition affecting the hands is mimicking Raynaud's?
